com.web_tomorrow.utils.javapopt
Class Popt

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--com.web_tomorrow.utils.javapopt.Popt
public class Popt
extends java.lang.Object

Java command-line argument parser V1.0 See `overview' for information on how to use this class. (c)2001 Kevin Boone/Web-Tomorrow, all rights reserved

Constructor Detail

Popt

public Popt(java.lang.String[] _args,
            boolean _longFormShort,
            boolean _strict,
            boolean _ignoreCase,
            boolean _numericSwitches)
The Popt constructor takes an array of Strings, typically as supplied on the command-line to a program, and a set of flags controlling the strictness of the parsing process. The String[] input can legitimately be empty; this will cause no problems, but it must not be null 
args          The arguments to parse

longFormShort true if the long name can be supplied with
only a single dash. This option is helpful 
only if there are no long-form arguments
that happen to have only one letter. The parser
does not check for this, as it is unusual in practice              

strict        if true, certain non-critical errors are
considered critical. For example, in strict
mode switches that are not in the client's
supplied list are considered an error; otherwise
they are silently ignored. Note, however, that if
a switch is not listed, we don't know if it should
take arguments, so we can't skip the arguments. This
may mean that parsing falls over further on instead.

ignoreCase    match case-insensitively on short names. Long names are
always match this way. If you set this flag, ensure
that there are no ambiguous short names. 

numericSwiches true if switches are allowed to begin with digits.
Only set this to true if you're sure you will require
numeric switches, because it prevents negative
numbers being used in arguments.

Popt

public Popt(java.lang.String[] _args)
The Popt constructor takes an array of Strings, typically as supplied on the command-line to a program, and uses default settings for the strictness parameters.
Method Detail

addNonSwitchSpec

public void addNonSwitchSpec(java.lang.String _identifier,
                             java.lang.String _argName,
                             boolean _compulsory,
                             java.lang.String _description,
                             java.lang.Class _argType)
addNonSwitchSpec() is called by clients to add non-switch args to the list recognized by the parser. It should be called once for each argument. 
identifier    name used to refer to this item after parsing

argName	      name of the argument, if there is one

compulsory    true if it would be an error to omit this argument 

description   short text description of the argument, for usage message

argType       type of the argument. Currently we recognise
String, Integer, and Double. Note that args are
always classes, never primitives
Note that non-swtich args are recognized by their order of appearance of the command line. Some or all may be optional, but it is erroneous to specify a compulsory argument _after_ an optional one (how would the parser know which arguments to insist on?)

addSwitchSpec

public void addSwitchSpec(java.lang.String identifier,
                          char shortName,
                          java.lang.String longName,
                          boolean compulsory,
                          java.lang.String description,
                          java.lang.String argName,
                          java.lang.Class argType,
                          boolean allowDuplicates)
addSwitchSpec() is called by clients to add switches to the list recognized by the parser. It should be called once for each switch. 
identifier    name used to refer to this item after parsing

shortName     short name of the switch, _without_ the
leading `-' 

longName      long name of the switch, _without_ the
leading `--' 

compulsory    true if it would be an error to omit this switch

description   short text description of the switch, for usage message

hasArg        true if this switch requires an argument

argName	      name of the argument, if there is one

argType       type of the argument. Currently we recognise
String, Integer, and Double. Note that args are
always classes, never primitives

addSwitchSpec

public void addSwitchSpec(java.lang.String identifier,
                          char shortName,
                          java.lang.String longName,
                          boolean compulsory,
                          java.lang.String description,
                          boolean allowDuplicates)
Convenience version of addSwitchSpec() for switches that don't take arguments (and therefore don't need to have them specified). 
identifier    name used to refer to this item after parsing

shortName     short name of the switch, _without_ the
leading `-' 

longName      long name of the switch, _without_ the
leading `--' 

compulsory    true if it would be an error to omit this switch

description   short text description of the switch, for usage message

addHelp

public void addHelp(boolean longHelp,
                    boolean shortHelp,
                    boolean query)
Adds the `help' switches to the argument list. This method can add between zero and three entries: longHelp recognizes `--help', shortHelp recognizes `-h' and query recognizes `-?'. Don't use shortHelp if you have other switches denoted by `-h'.

parse

public boolean parse()
parse() processes the command-line arguments

setPoptParseHandler

public void setPoptParseHandler(PoptParseHandler _poptParseHandler)
setPoptParseHandler sets that supplementary parser handler. The `handleArg' method in this class is called whenever an argument is matched, in addition to anything that might happen in the parser itself.

parseNonSwitchArgs

public boolean parseNonSwitchArgs()
parse() processes the command-line arguments that are _not_ switches. This method takes as its input the arguments left over from parsing the switches. Therefore, if a client does use this method (and it probably shouldn't), it should call parseSwitchArgs() first. Otherwise this method will do nothing

parseSwitchArgs

public boolean parseSwitchArgs()
parse() processes the switch command-line arguments, writing anything left over into leftoverArgs

supplied

public boolean supplied(java.lang.String identifier)
supplied() returns true if the command-line contained the specified argument. If the argument was a switch, and the switch did not take an argument, then this is probably the best way for the application to determine whether the argument was present or not

getArg

public java.lang.Object getArg(java.lang.String identifier)
getArg() gets an argument from the match table, if it is there, or null otherwise. If the argument was a switch, and the switch did not itself take an argument, then this method will return a Boolean object set to `true'. If the argument was a switch that took a value, then the value of the switch argument is returned. If the argument was a non-switch, the argument itself is returned. That is, in all cases the return value is something that is supplied on the command line, although in the `Boolean' case it is supplied implicitly

getInt

public int getInt(java.lang.String identifier)
getInt() gets the specified argument as an int primitive. This method can be handy if you know that the argument exists and is an integer (because it is compulsory). Otherwise don't use this without first checking that the argument exists, unless you are prepared to handle NullPointerException and ClassCastException...

getDoubleOrDefault

public double getDoubleOrDefault(java.lang.String identifier,
                                 double def)
getDoubleOrDefault() gets the specified argument as a double primitive, or returns the supplied default if the argument was not specified. It only makes sense to use this on non-compulsory arguments, as compulsory arguments will never take the default value. Note that the respone of this method is undefined if it is asked to return an attribute for which a value has been entered, but is of the wrong type. This can only be a coding error, because the user's input will already have been validated to be of the correct type for the argument specification supplied.

getIntOrDefault

public int getIntOrDefault(java.lang.String identifier,
                           int def)
getIntOrDefault() gets the specified argument as an int primitive, or returns the supplied default if the argument was not specified. It only makes sense to use this on non-compulsory arguments, as compulsory arguments will never take the default value. Note that the respone of this method is undefined if it is asked to return an attribute for which a value has been entered, but is of the wrong type. This can only be a coding error, because the user's input will already have been validated to be of the correct type for the argument specification supplied.

getStringOrDefault

public java.lang.String getStringOrDefault(java.lang.String identifier,
                                           java.lang.String def)
getStringOrDefault() gets the specified argument as a String or returns the supplied default if the argument was not specified. It only makes sense to use this on non-compulsory arguments, as compulsory arguments will never take the default value. Because anything can be converted into a String, this method works on any argument, regardless of type

getDouble

public double getDouble(java.lang.String identifier)
getDouble() gets the specified argument as an double primitive. This method can be handy if you know that the argument exists and is a double (because it is compulsory). Otherwise don't use this without first checking that the argument exists, unless you are prepared to handle NullPointerException and ClassCastException...

getString

public java.lang.String getString(java.lang.String identifier)
getString() gets the specified argument as a String. This method can be handy if you know that the argument exists and is a String (because it is compulsory). Otherwise don't use this without first checking that the argument exists, unless you are prepared to handle ClassCastException

addMatch

protected boolean addMatch(java.lang.String identifier,
                           java.lang.Object o)
addMatch() adds an argument to the match list, keyed by its identifier. Returns true if the entry was added. If it returns false, this indicates that the entry over-wrote an existing entry with the same name. This _may_ be an error (that's for the application to decide). So the caller of this methid should probably check the return value and take appropriate action. When called by parseSwitchArgs(), the parser will abort if this method returns false and `strict' is set.

findSwitchSpec

protected com.web_tomorrow.utils.javapopt.Popt.PoptSwitchSpec findSwitchSpec(java.lang.String arg)
Finds the switch arg specification, if it exists, based on the supplied arg. arg should include the dashes, because the algorithm needs to know whether to match the long form of the name or the short form. Returns null if the arg does not match anything. This method is called by parseSwitchArgs().

getLeftoverArgs

public java.lang.String[] getLeftoverArgs()
Returns an array of command-line arguments that were not matched as switches. These having meanings that are known only to the client. The array will be empty unless parse() has been called.

setLeftoverArgs

public void setLeftoverArgs(java.lang.String[] _leftoverArgs)
Sets the array of command-line arguments that were not matched as switches. A client application should probably not need to call this method directly, unless it wants to merge command-line arguments from different sources, for example. If you do call it, the only useful thing that can be done afterwards is parseNonSwitchArgs()

getShortUsage

public java.lang.String getShortUsage()
getShortUsage() returns a String that can be output to the console. This String contains a summary of the switches, without details. For a full usage message, use getUsage(). Note that in practice a client will need to use getShortUsage() and getUsage() together. getShortUsage() only displays switches; it does not display the text `usage:', or the program name, or the non-switch arguments. These must be prepended and appended by the client.

getUsage

public java.lang.String getUsage()
getUsage() returns a String that can be output to the console. This String contains a summary of the usage of the program, derived from the command-line arguments supplied by the client. Output will span multiple lines. For a one-line summary, use getShortUsage().

getUnmatchedSwitchMessage

protected java.lang.String getUnmatchedSwitchMessage()
Called to get an error message if a switch name is not matched. Override if you want a different message or a different language.

getDuplicateSwitchMessage

protected java.lang.String getDuplicateSwitchMessage()
Called to get an error message if a switch is supplied more than once. This may not be an error, depending on the application

getMissingArgumentMessage

protected java.lang.String getMissingArgumentMessage()
Called to get an error message if a switch that requires an argument does not have an argument.

getBadIntegerMessage

protected java.lang.String getBadIntegerMessage()
Called to get an error message if an argument defined to be an integer could not be converted to an integer

getMissingCompulsoryArgumentMessage

protected java.lang.String getMissingCompulsoryArgumentMessage()
Called to get an error message if an argument defined to be compulsory was not supplied on the command line

getBadDoubleMessage

protected java.lang.String getBadDoubleMessage()
Called to get an error message if an argument defined to be a double could not be converted to a double

getErrorMessage

public java.lang.String getErrorMessage()
Retrieves the last error message, if any. If there has been no error, returns null. This method can only usefully be called after one of the parsing methods; other methods don't set the error message

main

public static void main(java.lang.String[] args)
The main() method tests the JavaPopt parser. It accepts various command-line arguments, and displays the values entered. Use the --help switch to see which arguments are accepted
